body: Mmmyeah, this should be supported somehow. But the risk with not checking for the presence of `.stfolder` is that if you remove the SD card while syncthing is running, it won't detect the removal but will instead interpret is as a delete of all photos, and they will be deleted on the other devices as well.
Maybe it is possible to check if the mount /sdcard is mounted or not instead?
@schuft69 That may be bad idea, some Android devices will mount sdcardfs loopbacked to something like `/data/sdcard` if real sdcard is removed.

@kozec Maybe native method getExternalStorageState() can help?

https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Environment.html#MEDIA_MOUNTED

Can't you just create the file on the sdcard on a PC or something? It's a somewhat clumsy workaround, but still...
I know why I put CM on all my Kitkat devices ;)

issue.body:
This may be related to: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/1126

I noticed a minor problem with writing the ignore preferences from the GUI. Even if syncthing has permissions to edit .stignore, the fact that it tries to write to a temporary file first -- e.g., .syncthing.stignore-sharename123456789 -- prevents it from happening, if syncthing doesn't have write permissions for that folder. (I'm trying to set up a read-only share, where syncthing will simply observe the folder for backup purposes, and has limited permissions to that folder, since it doesn't/shouldn't need them.)

I can still edit .stignore just fine with vim. I bring that up because I know vim attempts to write to a backup file first, yet it can still handle writing with no complaints when there's no permission to create a backup file. I don't understand the mechanisms behind that, but it could be a simple exception case.

I can't think of the best solution, since temporary files are used for a good reason... If the syncthing configuration files were confined to their own specific folder, either a subfolder or elsewhere, it would be easier to handle situations like this, but not necessarily elegant...

I left the subject vague, since I don't know if it'd be desirable to extend to other situations, like synchronizing. That seems like it could be a bad idea, to me.

body: I have the same use-case as #1940 (syncing an encrypted copy of a folder to a potentially unsafe location). The source folder is read-only, and a virtual FS, so I can't write in it at all. Storing the configuration files (`.stfolder` and `.stignore`) in a specific folder would be useful in some cases.
Storing stfolder makes it useless, as explained, this file is there to detect when the folder was unmounted, versus all of the content was genuinely removed.
Oh right, I guessed it stored some information. My bad.

Would it be enough to allow a per folder property for the name of the
.stfolder file?

If, in a read only location, I could find some other existing file that's
unlikely to ever disappear, and tell syncthing to look for that file
instead, it might just solve this.

I managed to work around this problem by manually creating a .stfolder file using adb shell + touch in the root of the directory I wanted to synchronize, and it worked. It would probably work by mounting the SD card on a PC, too.

If no good fix can be found, it could be good to send a more comprehensible error message with this workaround proposal instead. It took me a while to understand why it was failing in the first place.

How about making the marker file name configurable per folder, of course defaulting to `.stfolder`. For cases where creating an .stfolder marker isn't feasible, the user can instead set it to the name of a folder or file that should always exist. Or possibly blank to disable it completely, with the appropriate warnings.

Making the marker file name configurable per folder would solve my problem. I'm planning to sync my [Seafile library mounted via FUSE](https://manual.seafile.com/extension/fuse.html) via Syncthing to a backup location. The filesystem is read only, so `.stfolder`can't be created. I've worked around this by syncing the parent folder instead (which is writable). But if FUSE or the Seafile server stop working and the mount becomes unavailable, only the .stfolder will remain and it will cause a mass deletion of all my files on the backup location...

Wow that was quick. Thanks!
